verses.text: Paul, an apostle of Christ Jesus by the will of God, to the saints who are in Ephesus and faithful in Christ Jesus:
verses.comment: Paul declares his apostolic authority, affirming his mission comes from the will of God. The greeting extends to all true believers, recognizing their special status as 'saints'.

verses.text: Grace to you and peace from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ.
verses.comment: The standard apostolic blessing, combining both Greek and Hebrew greetings—grace (charis) and peace (shalom)—which together are fulfilled in Christ.

verses.text: Blessed be the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, who has blessed us in Christ with every spiritual blessing in the heavenly places,
verses.comment: Paul introduces the theme of spiritual blessings, highlighting our union with Christ as the source of every heavenly gift—a recurring theme in his letters.

verses.text: just as he chose us in him before the foundation of the world, that we should be holy and blameless before him. In love
verses.comment: God’s election is presented as eternal and gracious. This verse echoes the Old Testament nation of Israel being set apart, yet here extended to all believers in Christ.

verses.text: he predestined us for adoption as sons through Jesus Christ, according to the purpose of his will,
verses.comment: Adoption as sons points toward an intimate relationship with God that transcends mere legal status—mirroring ancient Roman practice, where adoption bestows all rights of inheritance.

verses.text: to the praise of his glorious grace, with which he has blessed us in the Beloved.
verses.comment: The Beloved is a Messianic reference (Ps. 2:7; Matt. 3:17) identifying Jesus. All is done for God’s glory and as a testimony of his grace in Christ.

verses.text: In him we have redemption through his blood, the forgiveness of our trespasses, according to the riches of his grace,
verses.comment: Redemption is a financial and sacrificial term from the Old Testament, emphasizing the costliness of salvation—here, through the blood of Christ, fulfilling the requirements of atonement (Lev. 17:11).

verses.text: which he lavished upon us, in all wisdom and understanding
verses.comment: God’s grace is generously given in Christ, guided by divine wisdom. This hints at a deeper plan revealed through the New Covenant.

verses.text: making known to us the mystery of his will, according to his purpose, which he set forth in Christ
verses.comment: The ‘mystery’ refers to God’s long-hidden plan now revealed: the inclusion of all nations in the promise through Christ.

verses.text: as a plan for the fullness of time, to unite all things in him, things in heaven and things on earth.
verses.comment: God’s ultimate goal is cosmic unity in Christ, restoring harmony between heaven and earth, echoing creation and foreshadowing new creation (see Rev. 21:1–5).

verses.text: In him we have obtained an inheritance, having been predestined according to the purpose of him who works all things according to the counsel of his will,
verses.comment: Believers share in Christ’s inheritance. The language of predestination emphasizes God’s sovereignty and the assurance of the believer.

verses.text: so that we who were the first to hope in Christ might be to the praise of his glory.
verses.comment: The early Jewish believers (“first to hope”) have a special role, though the praise of God now encompasses all believers in God’s larger plan.

verses.text: In him you also, when you heard the word of truth, the gospel of your salvation, and believed in him, were sealed with the promised Holy Spirit,
verses.comment: The sealing of the Holy Spirit recalls Old Testament anointing of kings and priests, signifying God's claim and protection on the believer. This sealing is a sign of God's covenant relationship.

verses.text: who is the guarantee of our inheritance until we acquire possession of it, to the praise of his glory.
verses.comment: The Spirit is described as a down payment or pledge, offering assurance of future resurrection and full participation in the promises of God.

verses.text: For this reason, because I have heard of your faith in the Lord Jesus and your love toward all the saints,
verses.comment: Faith in Christ and love for the saints are presented as the intertwined marks of authentic Christian life, showing both right belief and right action.

verses.text: I do not cease to give thanks for you, remembering you in my prayers,
verses.comment: Paul’s constant thanksgiving and prayer underscore the value of intercession and ongoing remembrance within the community of believers.

verses.text: that the God of our Lord Jesus Christ, the Father of glory, may give you a spirit of wisdom and of revelation in the knowledge of him,
verses.comment: The prayer for wisdom and revealed knowledge draws on the Old Testament expectation of the Spirit resting upon the Messiah—see Isaiah 11:2.

verses.text: having the eyes of your hearts enlightened, that you may know what is the hope to which he has called you, what are the riches of his glorious inheritance in the saints,
verses.comment: Paul speaks of an enlightened heart—more than intellectual understanding, this is spiritual perception given through grace.

verses.text: and what is the immeasurable greatness of his power toward us who believe, according to the working of his great might
verses.comment: Paul assures believers of the extraordinary power available to them, the same power active in Christ’s resurrection.

verses.text: that he worked in Christ when he raised him from the dead and seated him at his right hand in the heavenly places,
verses.comment: Jesus' resurrection and enthronement at God’s right hand fulfills Old Testament Messianic prophecy (Ps. 110:1), affirming Jesus as both Messiah and divine Lord.

verses.text: far above all rule and authority and power and dominion, and above every name that is named, not only in this age but also in the age to come.
verses.comment: Christ is declared sovereign over all spiritual powers—both now and in the world to come—highlighting his unique authority.

verses.text: And he put all things under his feet and gave him as head over all things to the church,
verses.comment: God’s act of placing everything under Christ connects with Psalm 8; Christ is head over the church, establishing its unity and divine foundation, and preparation for later references to the structure and teaching authority of the church.

verses.text: which is his body, the fullness of him who fills all in all.
verses.comment: The church is described as the body of Christ—a mystical, organic union—indicating a visible, united body continuing Christ’s presence and ministry on earth.
